newsitem.title: RUSSIA: U.N. hostages freed in Tajikistan - Tass.
newsitem.headline: U.N. hostages freed in Tajikistan - Tass.

text.p: A rebel Tajik guerrilla group on Saturday released 21 of 23 hostages, including seven United Nations military observers it had threatened to kill, Itar-Tass news agency reported from the Tajik capital Dushanbe.
The rogue rebelsnued to hold two members of the Tajik opposition, the report said.
Diplomatic sources in Dushanbe confirmed the report. Earlier, the U.N. said the captives included two Bulgarians, a Dane, a Jordanian, a Ukrainian, a Uruguayan and an Austrian.
The rebel group is continuing to demand the release of four prisoners allied to their group before the last two hostages will be let free, the sources said.

Amirkul Azimov, Secretary of Tajikistan's Security Council, told Reuters in the capital Dushanbe earlier on Saturday the guerrillas, who say they are loyal to field commander Rizvon Sadirov, had agreed to free all hostages after all-night talks.

Sadirov had until recently been allied with the Islamic rebel opposition to Tajik President Imomali Rakhmonov, but switched to back the government of the former Soviet Republic, apparently without surrendering control of his forces.
